headline.main: Death Rate From Obesity Gains Fast On Smoking

docs.abstract: Report from Centers for Disease Control says that obesity is close to overtaking smoking as leading cause of death in US; reports that tobacco killed 435,000 people in 2000, 18.1 percent of Americans who died, while poor health and physical inactivity caused 400,000 deaths, 16.6 percent of total; estimated 64 percent of Americans are overweight or obese (S)

keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Obesity is near to overtaking smoking as the No. 1 cause of death in the United States, government researchers said on Tuesday, and other research shows that its adverse health effects could soon wipe out many recent improvements in health. A report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said that tobacco use was still the leading cause of death in 2000, killing 435,000 people, or 18.1 percent of everyone who died.
